Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story: I was in the lab, prepping the samples for the experiment I’d been planning for weeks. The hum of the centrifuge was oddly soothing, and I was finally in the zone. My phone buzzed, and I glanced at the screen—Sam, my oldest friend, was calling. I hesitated, but answered. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in screws and these instructions make no sense,” Sam pleaded, sounding genuinely frazzled. I glanced at the clock. The experiment could technically wait; there were other slots available, and missing this one wouldn’t derail my research. But I’d carved out this time, and I knew how easily momentum could slip away. Still, Sam rarely asked for help, and I could hear the frustration in their voice. I felt the tug of loyalty, the urge to be the friend who shows up in a pinch. At the same time, the scientist in me bristled at the idea of breaking my focus, of letting personal life intrude on carefully scheduled work. My mind raced, torn between the sterile certainty of the lab and the messy, immediate need of a friend.
